3-16:7. Mahidasa Aitareya (the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">son</span> of Itara), who knew
this, said (addressing a disease): `Why dost <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thou</span>
afflict me, as I shall not die by it?' He lived a hundred and
sixteen <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> (i.e. 24 + 44 + 48). He, too, who
knows this lives on to a hundred and sixteen years.
Section 17
Seventeenth Khanda
3-17:1. When a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> (who is the sacrificer) hungers,
thirsts, and abstains from pleasures, that is the
Diksha (initiatory rite).
3-17:2. When a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> eats, drinks, and enjoys pleasures,
he does it with the Upasadas (the sacrificial <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t6 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 hoverable">days</span>
on which the sacrificer is allowed to partake of food).
3-17:3. When a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> laughs, eats, and delights himself,
he does it with the Stuta-sastras (hymns sung and
recited at the sacrifices).
3-17:4. Penance, liberality, righteousness, kindness,
truthfulness, these <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">form</span> his Dakshinas (gifts
bestowed on priests, &c.)
3-17:5. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Therefore</span> when they say, `There will be a birth,'
and `there has been a birth' (words <span class="t4 hoverable">used</span> at the
Soma-sacrifice, and really meaning, `He will pour out the
Soma-juice,' and `he has poured out the Somajuice'), that is his new birth. His <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> is the Avabhritha
ceremony (when the sacrificial vessels are
carried away to be cleansed).
3-17:6. Ghora Angirasa, after having communicated this
(view of the sacrifice) to Krishna, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">son</span> of
112

Devaki and he never thirsted again (after other
knowledge) said: `Let a man, when his end
approaches, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">take</span> refuge with this Triad:
"Thou <span class="t2 t6 t8 t9 t10 t15 t18 t19 t21 t22 t23 t24 t28 t29 hoverable">art</span> the imperishable,"
"Thou <span class="t2 t6 t8 t9 t10 t15 t18 t19 t21 t22 t23 t24 t28 t29 hoverable">art</span> the unchangeable,"
"Thou <span class="t2 t6 t8 t9 t10 t15 t18 t19 t21 t22 t23 t24 t28 t29 hoverable">art</span> the edge of Prana."'
On this subject there are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> Rik verses (Rig-veda VIII, 6,
30):
3-17:7. `Then they see (within themselves) the everpresent <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> of the old seed (of the world, the Sat),
the highest, which is lighted in the brilliant (Brahman).'
Rig-veda 1, 50, 10:
`Perceiving above the darkness (of ignorance) the
<span class="t1 t5 t11 t16 hoverable">higher</span> <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> (in the sun), as the <span class="t1 t5 t11 t16 hoverable">higher</span> <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span> the
heart, the bright source (of <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> and life) among the gods,
we have reached the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">highest</span> light, yea, the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">highest</span> light.'
Section 18
Eighteenth Khanda
3-18:1. Let a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> meditate on <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Brahman</span> (n.), this
is said with reference to the body. Let a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span>
meditate on the ether as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Brahman</span> (n.), this is said with
reference to the Devas. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Thus</span> both the <span class="t25 hoverable">meditation</span>
which has reference to the body, and the <span class="t25 hoverable">meditation</span>
which has reference to the Devas, has been taught.
3-18:2. That <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Brahman</span> (mind) has four feet (quarters).
Speech is one foot, breath is one foot, the eye is
one foot, the ear is one foot so much with reference to
the body. Then with reference to the gods, <span class="t4 t6 t9 t10 t12 t14 t17 t18 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">Agni</span>
(fire) is one foot, Vayu (air) is one foot, Aditya (sun) is one
foot, the quarters are one foot. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Thus</span> both the
worship which has reference to the body, and the worship
which has reference to the Devas, has been
taught.

113

3-18:3. Speech is indeed the fourth foot of Brahman.
That foot shines with <span class="t4 t6 t9 t10 t12 t14 t17 t18 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">Agni</span> (fire) as its light, and
warms. He who knows this, shines and warms through
his celebrity, fame, and <span class="t0 t7 t21 t27 hoverable">glory</span> of countenance.
3-18:4. Breath is indeed the fourth foot of Brahman. That
foot shines with Vayu (air) as its light, and
warms. He who knows this, shines and warms through
his celebrity, fame, and <span class="t0 t7 t21 t27 hoverable">glory</span> of countenance.
3-18:5. The eye is indeed the fourth foot of Brahman.
That foot shines with Aditya (sun) as its light, and
warms. He who knows this, shines and warms through
his celebrity, fame, and <span class="t0 t7 t21 t27 hoverable">glory</span> of countenance.
3-18:6. The ear is indeed the fourth foot of Brahman.
That foot shines with the quarters as its light, and
warms. He who knows this, shines and warms through
his celebrity, fame, and <span class="t0 t7 t21 t27 hoverable">glory</span> of countenance.
Section 19
Nineteenth Khanda
3-19:1. Aditya (the sun) is Brahman, this is the doctrine,
and this is the fuller <span class="t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">account</span> of it:
In the beginning this was non-existent. It became
existent, it grew. It turned into an egg. The egg lay for
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> of a year. The egg broke open. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> halves
were one of silver, the other of gold.
3-19:2. The silver one became this earth, the golden one
the sky, the thick membrane (of the white) the
mountains, the thin membrane (of the yoke) the mist with
the clouds, the small veins the rivers, the fluid
the sea.
3-19:3. And what was <span class="t16 t24 hoverable">born</span> from it that was Aditya, the
sun. When he was <span class="t16 t24 hoverable">born</span> shouts of hurrah arose,
and all <span class="t1 t4 t8 t16 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">beings</span> arose, and all <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">things</span> which they desired.
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Therefore</span> whenever the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">sun</span> rises and sets, shouts
of hurrah arise, and all <span class="t1 t4 t8 t16 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">beings</span> arise, and all <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">things</span> which
they desire.

114

3-19:4. If any one knowing this meditates on the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">sun</span> as
Brahman, pleasant shouts will approach him and
will continue, yea, they will continue.
End of <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">Chapter</span> 3
~ <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">Chapter</span> 4 ~
Fourth Prapathaka
Section 1
First Khanda
4-1:1. There lived once <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> Ganasruti
Pautrayana (the great-grandson of Ganasruta), who was
a
pious giver, bestowing much wealth <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the people, and
always keeping open house. He built places of
refuge everywhere, wishing that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> should
everywhere <span class="t28 hoverable">eat</span> of his food.
4-1:2. Once in the night some Hamsas (flamingoes) flew
over his house, and one flamingo said to
another: `Hey, Bhallaksha, Bhallaksha (short-sighted
friend). The <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> (glory) of Ganasruti Pautrayana
has spread like the sky. Do not go near, that it may not
burn thee.'
4-1:3. The other answered him: `How can you <span class="t9 t11 t20 t21 t22 t23 t27 hoverable">speak</span> of
him, being what he is (a raganya, noble), as if he
were like Raikva with the car?'
4-1:4. The first replied: `How is it with this Raikva with the
car of whom <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thou</span> speakest?'
The other answered: `As (in a game of dice) all the lower
casts belong to him who has conquered with the
Krita cast, so whatever <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> deeds other <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> perform,
belong to that Raikva. He who knows what he
knows, he is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> spoken of by me.'
4-1:5. Ganasruti Pautrayana overheard this
conversation, and as soon as he had risen in the
morning, he
115

said to his door-keeper (kshattri): `Friend, dost <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thou</span> <span class="t9 t11 t20 t21 t22 t23 t27 hoverable">speak</span>
of (me, as if I were) Raikva with the car?'
He replied: `How is it with this Raikva with the car?'
4-1:6. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">king</span> said: `As (in a game of dice), all the lower
casts belong to him who has conquered with
the Krita cast, so whatever <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> deeds other <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span>
perform, belong to that Raikva. He who knows what
he knows, he is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> spoken of by me.'
4-1:7. The door-keeper <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">went</span> to look for Raikva, but
returned saying, `I found him not.' Then the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">king</span>
said: `Alas! where a Brahmana should be searched for (in
the solitude of the forest), there go for him.'
4-1:8. The door-keeper came to a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> who was lying
beneath a car and scratching his sores. He
addressed him, and said: `Sir, are you Raikva with the
car?'
He answered: `Here I am.'
Then the door-keeper returned, and said: `I have found
him.'
Section 2
<span class="t2 t3 t5 t10 t12 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">Second</span> Khanda
4-2:1. Then Ganasruti Pautrayana <span class="t0 t7 t11 t13 t14 t22 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">took</span> six hundred
cows, a necklace, and a carriage with mules, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">went</span> to
Raikva and said:
4-2:2. `Raikva, here are six hundred cows, a necklace,
and a carriage with mules; teach me the deity
which you worship.'
4-2:3. The other replied: `Fie, necklace and carriage be
thine, O Sudra, <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t9 t11 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">together</span> with the cows.'
The Ganasruti Pautrayana <span class="t0 t7 t11 t13 t14 t22 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">took</span> again a <span class="t15 t23 hoverable">thousand</span> cows, a
necklace, a carriage with mules, and his own
daughter, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">went</span> to him.

116

4-2:4. He said to him: `Raikva, there are a <span class="t15 t23 hoverable">thousand</span>
cows, a necklace, a carriage with mules, this wife,
and this village in which <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thou</span> dwellest. Sir, teach me!'
4-2:5. He, opening her mouth, said: `You have <span class="t0 t4 t6 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t19 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">brought</span>
these (cows and other presents), O Sudra, but
only by that mouth did you make me speak.'
These are the Raikva-parna villages in the country of the
Mahavrishas (mahapunyas) where Raikva dwelt
under him. And he said to him:
Section 3
<span class="t7 hoverable">Third</span> Khanda
4-3:1. `Air (vayu) is indeed the end of all. For when <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span>
goes out, it goes into air. When the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">sun</span> goes
down, it goes into air. When the moon goes down, it
goes into air.
4-3:2. `When <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> dries up, it goes into air. Air indeed
consumes them all. So much with reference to
the Devas.
4-3:3. `Now with reference to the body. Breath (prana) is
indeed the end of all. When a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> sleeps,
speech goes into breath, so do sight, hearing, and mind.
Breath indeed consumes them all.
4-3:4. `These are the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> ends, air among the Devas,
breath among the senses (pranah).'

4-3:5. Once while Saunaka Kapeya and Abhipratarin
Kakshaseni were being waited on at their meal, a
religious student begged of them. They gave him
nothing.
4-3:6. He said: `One <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">god</span> who is he? swallowed the
four <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> ones, he, the guardian of the world.
O Kapeya, mortals see him not, O Abhipratarin, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span>
he dwells in many places. He to whom this <span class="t2 t4 t11 t13 hoverable">food</span>
belongs, to him it has not been given.'
117

4-3:7. Saunaka Kapeya, pondering on that speech, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">went</span>
to the student and said: `He is the self of the
Devas, the creator of all beings, with golden tusks, the
eater, not <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> intelligence. His greatness is
said to be <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> indeed, because, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> being eaten, he
eats even what is not food. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Thus</span> do we, O
Brahmakarin, meditate on that Being.' Then he said:
`Give him food.'
4-3:8. They gave him food. Now these five (the eater
Vayu (air), and his food, <span class="t4 t6 t9 t10 t12 t14 t17 t18 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">Agni</span> (fire), Aditya (sun),
Kandramas (moon), Ap (water)) and the other five (the
eater Prana (breath), and his food, speech, sight,
hearing, mind) make ten, and that is the Krita (the
highest) cast (representing the ten, the eaters and the
food). <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Therefore</span> in all quarters those ten are <span class="t2 t4 t11 t13 hoverable">food</span> (and)
Krita (the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">highest</span> cast). These are again the
Virag (of ten syllables) which eats the food. Through this
all this becomes seen. He who knows this sees
all this and becomes an eater of food, yea, he becomes
an eater of food.
Section 4
Fourth Khanda
4-4:1. Satyakama, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">son</span> of Gabala, addressed his
mother and said: `I wish to become a Brahmakarin
(religious student), mother. Of what family am I?'
4-4:2. She said to him: `I do not know, my child, of what
family <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thou</span> art. In my youth when I had to
move about much as a servant (waiting on the guests in
my father's house), I conceived thee. I do not
know of what family <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thou</span> art. I am Gabala by name, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thou</span>
<span class="t2 t6 t8 t9 t10 t15 t18 t19 t21 t22 t23 t24 t28 t29 hoverable">art</span> Satyakama (Philalethes). Say that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thou</span> <span class="t2 t6 t8 t9 t10 t15 t18 t19 t21 t22 t23 t24 t28 t29 hoverable">art</span>
Satyakama Gabala.'
4-4:3. He going to Gautama Haridrumata said to him, `I
wish to become a Brahmakarin with you, Sir.
May I come to you, Sir?'
4-4:4. He {Gautama} said to him: `Of what family are you,
my friend?' He {Satyakama} replied: `I do
not know, Sir, of what family I am. I asked my mother,
and she answered: "In my youth when I had to
118

move about much as a servant, I conceived thee. I do
not know of what family <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thou</span> art. I am Gabala by
name, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thou</span> <span class="t2 t6 t8 t9 t10 t15 t18 t19 t21 t22 t23 t24 t28 t29 hoverable">art</span> Satyakama," I am <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span> Satyakama
Gabala, Sir.'
4-4:5. He said to him: `No one but a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> Brahmana
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> <span class="t9 t11 t20 t21 t22 t23 t27 hoverable">speak</span> out. Go and fetch fuel, friend, I
shall initiate you. You have not swerved from the truth.'
Having initiated him, he chose four hundred lean and
weak cows, and said: `Tend these, friend.' He drove
them out and said to himself, `I shall not return unless I
<span class="t4 t6 t7 t9 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t22 t23 t24 t26 t27 hoverable">bring</span> back a thousand.' He dwelt a <span class="t3 t17 t26 hoverable">number</span> of
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> (in the forest), and when the cows had become a
thousand,
Section 5
Fifth Khanda
4-5:1. The bull of the herd (meant for Vayu) said to him:
`Satyakama!' He replied: `Sir!' The bull said:
`We have become a thousand, lead us to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">house</span> of
the teacher;
4-5:2. `And I will declare to you one foot of Brahman.'
`Declare it, Sir,' he replied.
He said to him: `The eastern region is one quarter, the
western region is one quarter, the southern region
is one quarter, the northern region is one quarter. This is
a foot of Brahman, consisting of the four
quarters, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> Prakasavat (endowed with
splendour).
4-5:3. `He who knows this and meditates on the foot of
Brahman, consisting of four quarters, by the name
of Prakasavat, becomes endowed with splendour in this
world. He conquers the resplendent worlds,
whoever knows this and meditates on the foot of
Brahman, consisting of the four quarters, by the name of
Prakasavat.
Section 6
119

Sixth Khanda
4-6:1. `Agni will declare to you another foot of Brahman.'
(After these <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">words</span> of the bull), Satyakama, on the
morrow, drove the cows (toward the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">house</span> of the
teacher). And when they came towards the evening, he
lighted a fire, penned the cows, laid wood on the
fire, and sat down behind the fire, looking to the east.
4-6:2. Then <span class="t4 t6 t9 t10 t12 t14 t17 t18 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">Agni</span> (the fire) said to him: `Satyakama!' He
replied: `Sir.'
4-6:3. <span class="t4 t6 t9 t10 t12 t14 t17 t18 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">Agni</span> said: `Friend, I will declare <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> you one foot
of Brahman.'
`Declare it, Sir,' he replied.
He said to him: `The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> is one quarter, the sky is one
quarter, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">heaven</span> is one quarter, the ocean is
one quarter. This is a foot of Brahman, consisting of four
quarters, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> Anantavat (endless).
4-6:4. `He who knows this and meditates on the foot of
Brahman, consisting of four quarters, by the name
of Anantavat, becomes endless in this world. He
conquers the endless worlds, whoever knows this and
meditates on the foot of Brahman, consisting of four
quarters, by the name of Anantavat.
Section 7
Seventh Khanda
4-7:1. `A Hamsa (flamingo, meant for the sun) will
declare to you another foot of Brahman.'
(After these <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">words</span> of Agni), Satyakama, on the morrow,
drove the cows onward. And when they came
towards the evening, he lighted a fire, penned the cows,
laid wood on the fire, and sat down behind the
fire, looking toward the east.
4-7:2. Then a Hamsa flew near and said to him:
`Satyakama.' He replied: `Sir.'
120

4-7:3. The Hamsa said: `Friend, I will declare <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> you
one foot of Brahman.'
`Declare it, Sir,' he replied.
He said to him: `Fire is one quarter, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">sun</span> is one
quarter, the moon is one quarter, lightning is one
quarter. This is a foot of Brahman, consisting of four
quarters, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> Gyotishmat (full of light).
4-7:4. `He who knows this and meditates on the foot of
Brahman, consisting of four quarters, by the name
of Gyotishmat, becomes <span class="t5 hoverable">full</span> of <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> in this world. He
conquers the worlds which are <span class="t5 hoverable">full</span> of light,
whoever knows this and meditates on the foot of
Brahman, consisting of four quarters, by the name of
Gyotishmat.
Section 8
Eighth Khanda
4-8:1. `A diver-bird (Madgu, meant for Pran) will declare
to you another foot of Brahman.'
(After these <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">words</span> of the Hamsa), Satyakama, on the
morrow, drove the cows onward. And when they
came towards the evening, he lighted a fire, penned the
cows, laid wood on the fire, and sat down behind
the fire, looking toward the east.
4-8:2. Then a diver flew near and said to him:
`Satyakama.' He replied: `Sir.'
4-8:3. The diver said: `Friend, I will declare <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> you one
foot of Brahman.'
`Declare it, Sir,' he replied.
He said to him: `Breath is one quarter, the eye is one
quarter, the ear is one quarter, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> is one
quarter. This is a foot of Brahman, consisting of four
quarters, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> Ayatanavat (having a home).
`He who knows this and meditates on the foot of
Brahman, consisting of four quarters, by the name of
121

Ayatanavat, becomes possessed of a home in this world.
He conquers the worlds which offer a home,
whoever knows this and meditates on the foot of
Brahman, consisting of four quarters, by the name of
Ayatanavat.'
Section 9
Ninth Khanda
4-9:1. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Thus</span> he reached the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">house</span> of his teacher. The
teacher said to him: `Satyakama.' He replied: `Sir.'
4-9:2. The teacher said: `Friend, you shine like one who
knows Brahman. Who then has taught you?' He
replied: `Not men. But you only, Sir, I wish, should teach
me;
4-9:3. `For I have <span class="t13 t14 t15 t18 t27 hoverable">heard</span> from <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> like you, Sir, that only
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> which is learnt from a teacher
(Akarya), leads to real good.' Then he taught him the
same knowledge. Nothing was <span class="t3 t13 t18 t24 hoverable">left</span> out, yea,
nothing was <span class="t3 t13 t18 t24 hoverable">left</span> out.
Section 10
Tenth Khanda
4-10:1. Upakosala Kamalayana dwelt as a Brahmakarin
(religious student) in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">house</span> of Satyakama
Gabala. He tended his fires for twelve years. But the
teacher, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> he allowed other pupils (after they
had learnt the sacred books) to depart to their own
homes, did not allow Upakosala to depart.
4-10:2. Then his wife said to him: `This student, who is
quite exhausted (with austerities), has carefully
tended your fires. Let not the fires themselves blame
you, but teach him.' The teacher, however, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">went</span>
away on a journey <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> having taught him.
4-10:3. The student from sorrow was not able to eat.
Then the wife of the teacher said to him: `Student,
eat! Why do you not eat?' He said: `There are many
desires in this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> here, which lose themselves in
122

different directions. I am <span class="t5 hoverable">full</span> of sorrows, and shall <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">take</span> no
food.'
4-10:4. Thereupon the fires said among themselves:
`This student, who is quite exhausted, has carefully
tended us. Well, let us teach him.' They said to him:
4-10:5. `Breath is Brahman, Ka (pleasure) is Brahman,
Kha (ether) is Brahman.'
He said: `I understand that breath is Brahman, but I do
not understand Ka or Kha.'
They said: `What is Ka is Kha, what is Kha is Ka.' They
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span> taught him <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Brahman</span> as breath, and as
the ether (in the heart).
Section 11
Eleventh Khanda
4-11:1. After that the Garhapatya <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> taught him: `Earth,
fire, food, and the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">sun</span> (these are my forms, or
forms of Brahman). The <span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">person</span> that is seen in the sun, I
am he, I am he indeed.
4-11:2. `He who knowing this meditates on him, destroys
sin, obtains the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> (of <span class="t4 t6 t9 t10 t12 t14 t17 t18 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">Agni</span> Garhapatya),
reaches his <span class="t5 hoverable">full</span> age, and lives long; his descendants do
not perish. We guard him in this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> and in the
other, whosoever knowing this meditates on him.'
Section 12
Twelfth Khanda
4-12:1. Then the Anvaharya <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> taught him: `Water, the
quarters, the stars, the moon (these are my
forms). The <span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">person</span> that is seen in the moon, I am he, I
am he indeed.
4-12:2. `He who knowing this meditates on him, destroys
sin, obtains the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> (of <span class="t4 t6 t9 t10 t12 t14 t17 t18 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">Agni</span> Anvaharya),
reaches his <span class="t5 hoverable">full</span> age, and lives long; his descendants do
not perish. We guard him in this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> and in the
other, whosoever knowing this meditates on him.'
123

Section 13
Thirteenth Khanda
4-13:1. Then the Ahavaniya <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> taught him: `Breath,
ether, heaven, and lightning (these are my forms).
The <span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">person</span> that is seen in the lightning, I am he, I am he
indeed.
4-13:2. `He who knowing this meditates on him, destroys
sin, obtains the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> (of <span class="t4 t6 t9 t10 t12 t14 t17 t18 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">Agni</span> Ahavaniya),
reaches his <span class="t5 hoverable">full</span> age, and lives long; his descendants do
not perish. We guard him in this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> and in the
other, whosoever knowing this meditates on him.'
Section 14
Fourteenth Khanda
4-14:1. Then they all said: `Upakosala, this is our
knowledge, our friend, and the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> of the Self,
but the teacher will tell you the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> (to another life).'
4-14:2. In <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> his teacher came back, and said to him:
`Upakosala.' He answered: `Sir.' The teacher
said: `Friend, your face shines like that of one who knows
Brahman. Who has taught you?'
`Who should teach me, Sir?' he said. He denies, as it
were. And he said (pointing) to the fires: `Are these
fires other than fires?'
The teacher said: `What, my friend, have these fires told
you?'
4-14:3. He answered: `This' (repeating some of what
they had told him).
The teacher said: `My friend, they have taught you about
the worlds, but I shall tell you this; and as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span>
does not cling to a lotus leaf, so no <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> deed clings to one
who knows it.' He said: `Sir, tell it {to} me.'
Section 15
124

Fifteenth Khanda
4-15:1. He said: `The <span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">person</span> that is seen in the eye, that
is the Self. This is the immortal, the fearless,
this is Brahman. Even <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> they drop melted butter or
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> on him, it runs away on both sides.
4-15:2. `They <span class="t3 t11 t18 t27 hoverable">call</span> him Samyadvama, for all blessings
(vama) go towards him (samyanti). All blessings
go towards him who knows this.
4-15:3. `He is also Vamani, for he leads (nayati) all
blessings (vama). He leads all blessings who knows
this.
4-15:4. `He is also Bhamani, for he shines (bhati) in all
worlds. He who knows this, shines in all worlds.
4-15:5. `Now (if one who knows this, dies), <span class="t10 t12 t16 t20 t21 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">whether</span>
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> perform obsequies for him or no, he goes to
<span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> (arkis), from <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> to day, from <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> to the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> half of
the moon, from the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> half of the moon to
the six months during which the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">sun</span> goes to the north,
from the months to the year, from the year to the
sun, from the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">sun</span> to the moon, from the moon to the
lightning. There is a <span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">person</span> not human,
4-15:6. `He leads them to Brahman. This is the path of
the Devas, the path that leads to Brahman.
Those who proceed on that path, do not return to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span>
of man, yea, they do not return.'
Section 16
Sixteenth Khanda
4-16:1. Verily, he who purifies (Vayu) is the sacrifice, for
he (the air) moving along, purifies everything.
Because moving along he purifies everything, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span>
he is the sacrifice. Of that <span class="t2 t9 t10 t16 t18 t19 t27 t28 hoverable">sacrifice</span> there are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span>
ways, by <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> and by speech.
4-16:2. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Brahman</span> priest performs one of them in his
mind, the Hotri, Adhvaryu, and Udgatri priests
perform the other by words. When the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Brahman</span> priest,
after the Prataranuvaka ceremony has begun, but
125

before the recitation of the Paridhaniya hymn, has (to
break his silence and) to speak,
4-16:3. He performs perfectly the one <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> only (that by
words), but the other is injured. As a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span>
walking on one foot, or a carriage going on one wheel, is
injured, his <span class="t2 t9 t10 t16 t18 t19 t27 t28 hoverable">sacrifice</span> is injured, and with the
injured <span class="t2 t9 t10 t16 t18 t19 t27 t28 hoverable">sacrifice</span> the sacrificer is injured; yes, having
sacrificed, he becomes worse.
4-16:4. But when after the Prataranuvaka ceremony has
begun, and before the recitation of the
Paridhaniya hymn, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Brahman</span> priest has not (to break
his silence and) to speak, they perform both ways
perfectly, and neither of them is injured.
4-16:5. As a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> walking on <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> legs and a carriage
going on <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> wheels gets on, so his <span class="t2 t9 t10 t16 t18 t19 t27 t28 hoverable">sacrifice</span> gets
on, and with the successful <span class="t2 t9 t10 t16 t18 t19 t27 t28 hoverable">sacrifice</span> the sacrificer gets
on; yes, having sacrificed, he becomes better.
Section 17
Seventeenth Khanda
4-17:1. Pragapati brooded over the worlds, and from
them <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> brooded on he squeezed out the essences,
<span class="t4 t6 t9 t10 t12 t14 t17 t18 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">Agni</span> (fire) from the earth, Vayu (air) from the sky, Aditya
(the sun) from heaven.
4-17:2. He brooded over these <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> deities, and from
them <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> brooded on he squeezed out the essences,
the Rik verses from Agni, the Yagus verses from Vayu,
the Saman verses from Aditya.
4-17:3. He brooded over the threefold <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> (the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> Vedas), and from it <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> brooded on he
squeezed out the essences, the sacred interjection Bhus
from the Rik verses, the sacred interjection Bhuvas
from the Yagus verses, the sacred interjection Svar from
the Saman verses.
4-17:4. If the <span class="t2 t9 t10 t16 t18 t19 t27 t28 hoverable">sacrifice</span> is injured from the Rig-veda side,
let him offer a libation in the Garhapatya fire,
saying, Bhuh, Svaha! <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Thus</span> does he bind <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t9 t11 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">together</span> and
heal, by means of the essence and the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> of the
126

Rik verses themselves, whatever break the Rik <span class="t2 t9 t10 t16 t18 t19 t27 t28 hoverable">sacrifice</span>
may have suffered.
4-17:5. If the <span class="t2 t9 t10 t16 t18 t19 t27 t28 hoverable">sacrifice</span> is injured from the Yagur-veda
side, let him offer a libation in the Dakshina fire,
saying, Bhuvah, Svaha! <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Thus</span> does he bind <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t9 t11 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">together</span> and
heal, by means of the essence and the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> of
the Yagus verses themselves, whatever break the Yagus
<span class="t2 t9 t10 t16 t18 t19 t27 t28 hoverable">sacrifice</span> may have suffered.
4-17:6. If the <span class="t2 t9 t10 t16 t18 t19 t27 t28 hoverable">sacrifice</span> is injured by the Sama-veda side,
let him offer a libation in the Ahavaniya fire,
saying, Svah, Svaha! <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Thus</span> does he bind <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t9 t11 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">together</span> and
heal, by means of the essence and the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> of the
Saman verses themselves, whatever break the Saman
<span class="t2 t9 t10 t16 t18 t19 t27 t28 hoverable">sacrifice</span> may have suffered.
4-17:7. As one binds (softens) gold by means of lavana
(borax), and silver by means of gold, and tin by
means of silver, and lead by means of tin, and iron (loha)
by means of lead, and wood by means of iron, or
also by means of leather,
4-17:8. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Thus</span> does one bind <span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t9 t11 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">together</span> and heal any break
in the <span class="t2 t9 t10 t16 t18 t19 t27 t28 hoverable">sacrifice</span> by means of (the Vyahritis or
sacrificial interjections which are) the essence and
strength of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> worlds, of the deities, and of the
threefold knowledge. That <span class="t2 t9 t10 t16 t18 t19 t27 t28 hoverable">sacrifice</span> is healed in which
there is a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Brahman</span> priest who knows this.
4-17:9. That <span class="t2 t9 t10 t16 t18 t19 t27 t28 hoverable">sacrifice</span> is inclined towards the north (in the
right way) in which there is a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Brahman</span> priest
who knows this. And with regard to such a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Brahman</span>
priest there is the following Gatha: `Wherever it
falls back, thither the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> goes,' viz. the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Brahman</span> only,
as one of the Ritvig priests. `He saves the
Kurus as a mare' (viz. a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Brahman</span> priest who knows this,
saves the sacrifice, the sacrificer, and all the
other priests). <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Therefore</span> let a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> make him who knows
this his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Brahman</span> priest, not one who does not
know it, who does not know it.
End of <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">Chapter</span> 4
