Yagnavalkya said: `Soma.'
Sakalya said: `In what does that Soma abide?'
Yagnavalkya said: `In the Diksha.'
Sakalya said: `In what does the Diksha abide?'
Yagnavalkya said: `In the True; and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span> they say to
one who has performed the Diksha, <span class="t9 t11 t20 t21 t22 t23 t27 hoverable">Speak</span> what
is true, for in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">True</span> indeed the Diksha abides.'
Sakalya said: `And in what does the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">True</span> abide?'
Yagnavalkya said: `In the heart, for with the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">heart</span> do we
know what is true, and in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">heart</span> indeed the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">True</span> abides.'
Sakalya said: `So it is indeed, O Yagnavalkya.'
3-9:24. Sakalya said: `Which is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thy</span> deity in the zenith?'
Yagnavalkya said: `Agni.'
Sakalya said: `In what does that <span class="t4 t6 t9 t10 t12 t14 t17 t18 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">Agni</span> abide.'
Yagnavalkya said: `In speech.'
Sakalya said: `And in what does speech abide?'
Yagnavalkya said: `In the heart.'
Sakalya said: `And in what does the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">heart</span> abide?'
3-9:25. Yagnavalkya said: `O Ahallika, when you think
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">heart</span> could be anywhere else away from us, if
it were away from us, the dogs might <span class="t28 hoverable">eat</span> it, or the birds
tear it.'
3-9:26. Sakalya said: `And in what dost <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thou</span> (thy body)
and the Self (thy heart) abide?'
Yagnavalkya said: `In the Prana (breath).'
Sakalya said: `In what does the Prana abide?'
406

Yagnavalkya said: `In the Apana (down-breathing).'
Sakalya said: `In what does the Apana abide?'
Yagnavalkya said: `In the Vyana (back-breathing).'
Sakalya said: `In what does the Vyana abide?'
Yagnavalkya said: `In the Udana (the out-breathing).'
Sakalya said: `In what does the Udana abide?'
Yagnavalkya said: `In the Samana. That Self (atman) is
to be described by No, no! He is
incomprehensible, for he cannot be (is not)
comprehended; he is imperishable, for he cannot perish;
he is
unattached, for he does not attach himself; unfettered, he
does not suffer, he does not fail.'
`These are the eight abodes (the earth, &c.), the eight
worlds (fire, &c.), the eight <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">gods</span> (the immortal
food, &c.), the eight persons (the corporeal, &c.) He who
after dividing and uniting these persons, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">went</span>
beyond (the Samana), that person, taught in the
Upanishads, I now ask <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thee</span> (to teach me). If <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thou</span> <span class="t0 t6 t7 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t20 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">shalt</span>
not explain him to me, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thy</span> <span class="t7 t11 t15 t22 hoverable">head</span> will fall.'
Sakalya did not know him, and his <span class="t7 t11 t15 t22 hoverable">head</span> fell, nay, thieves
<span class="t0 t7 t11 t13 t14 t22 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">took</span> away his bones, mistaking them for
something else.
3-9:27. Then Yagnavalkya said: `Reverend Brahmanas,
whosoever among you desires to do so, may now
question me. Or question me, all of you. Or whosoever
among you desires it, I shall question him, or I
shall question all of you.
But those Brahmanas durst not (say anything).
3-9:28. Then Yagnavalkya questioned them with these
Slokas:
1. `As a mighty tree in the forest, so in <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">truth</span> is man, his
hairs are the leaves, his outer skin is the bark.
407

2. `From his skin flows forth blood, sap from the skin (of
the tree); and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> from the wounded <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span>
comes forth blood, as from a tree that is struck.
3. `The lumps of his <span class="t21 hoverable">flesh</span> are (in the tree) the layers of
wood, the fibre is strong like the tendons. The
bones are the (hard) wood within, the marrow is made like
the marrow of the tree.
4. `But, while the tree, when felled, grows up again more
young from the root, from what root, tell me,
does a mortal grow up, after he has been felled by death?
5. `Do not say, "from seed," for seed is produced from
the living; but a tree, springing from a grain,
clearly rises again after death.
6. `If a tree is pulled up with the root, it will not grow
again; from what root then, tell me, does a mortal
grow up, after he has been felled by death?
7. `Once born, he is not <span class="t16 t24 hoverable">born</span> (again); for who should
create him again?'
`Brahman, who is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> and bliss, he is the
principle, both to him who gives gifts, and also to him
who stands firm, and knows.'
End of <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">Chapter</span> 3
~ <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">Chapter</span> 4 ~
Fourth Adhyaya
Section 1
First Brahmana
4-1:1. When Ganaka Vaideha was sitting (to give
audience), Yagnavalkya approached, and Ganaka
Vaideha said: `Yagnavalkya, for what <span class="t2 hoverable">object</span> did you
come, wishing for cattle, or for subtle questions?'
Yagnavalkya replied: `For both, Your Majesty;
408

4-1:2. `Let us hear what anybody may have told you.'
Ganaka Vaideha replied: `Gitvan Sailini told me
that speech (vak) is Brahman.'
Yagnavalkya said: `As one who had (the benefit of a
good) father, mother, and teacher might tell, so did
Sailini tell you, that speech is Brahman; for what is the
<span class="t4 t18 hoverable">use</span> of a dumb person? But did he tell you the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> (ayatana) and the resting-place (pratishtha) of that
Brahman?'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `He did not tell me.'
Yagnavalkya said: `Your Majesty, this (Brahman) stands
on one leg only.'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `Then tell me, Yagnavalkya.'
Yagnavalkya said: `The tongue is its body, ether its place,
and one should worship it as knowledge.'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `What is the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> of that
knowledge?'
Yagnavalkya replied: `Your Majesty, speech itself (is
knowledge). For through speech, Your Majesty, a
friend is known (to be a friend), and likewise the Rigveda, Yagur-veda, Sama-veda, the Atharvangirasas,
the Itihasa (tradition), Purana-vidya (knowledge of the
past), the Upanishads, Slokas (verses), Sutras
(rules), Anuvyakhyanas and Vyakhyanas (commentaries,
&c.); what is sacrificed, what is poured out,
what is (to be) eaten and drunk, this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> and the other
world, and all creatures. By speech alone, Your
Majesty, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Brahman</span> is known, speech indeed, O King, is
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">Highest</span> Brahman. Speech does not desert him
who worships that (Brahman) with such knowledge, all
creatures approach him, and having become a
god, he goes to the gods.'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `I shall give you (for this) a
<span class="t15 t23 hoverable">thousand</span> cows with a bull as big as an elephant.'
Yagnavalkya said: `My <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">father</span> was of opinion that one
should not accept a reward <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> having fully
instructed a pupil.'
409

4-1:3. Yagnavalkya said: `Let us hear what anybody may
have told you.'
Ganaka Vaideha replied: `Udanka Saulbayana told me
that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> (prana) is Brahman.'
Yagnavalkya said: `As one who had (the benefit of a
good) father, mother, and teacher might tell, so did
Udanka Saulbayana tell you that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> is Brahman; for what
is the <span class="t4 t18 hoverable">use</span> of a <span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">person</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> life? But did he
tell you the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> and the resting-place of that Brahman?'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `He did not tell me.'
Yagnavalkya said: `Your Majesty, this (Brahman) stands
on one leg only.'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `Then tell me, Yagnavalkya.'
Yagnavalkya said: `Breath is its body, ether its place, and
one should worship it as what is dear.'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `What is the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> of that which is
dear?'
Yagnavalkya replied: `Your Majesty, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> itself (is that
which is dear);' because for the sake of life, Your
Majesty, a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> sacrifices even for him who is unworthy of
sacrifice, he accepts presents from him who is
not worthy to bestow presents, nay, he goes to a country,
even when there is <span class="t28 hoverable">fear</span> of being hurt, for the
sake of life. Life, O King, is the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">Highest</span> Brahman. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Life</span>
does not desert him who worships that
(Brahman) with such knowledge, all creatures approach
him, and having become a god, he goes to the
gods.'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `I shall give you (for this) a
<span class="t15 t23 hoverable">thousand</span> cows with a bull as big as an elephant.'
Yagnavalkya said: `My <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">father</span> was of opinion that one
should not accept a reward <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> having fully
instructed a pupil.'

410

4-1:4. Yagnavalkya said: `Let us hear what anybody may
have told you.'
Ganaka Vaideha replied: `Barku Varshna told me that
sight (kakshus) is Brahman.'
Yagnavalkya said: `As one who had (the benefit of a
good) father, mother, and teacher might tell, so did
Barku Varshna tell you that sight is Brahman; for what is
the <span class="t4 t18 hoverable">use</span> of a <span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">person</span> who cannot see? But did he
tell you the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> and the resting-place of that Brahman?'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `He did not tell me.'
Yagnavalkya said: `Your Majesty, this (Brahman) stands
on one leg only.'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `Then tell me, Yagnavalkya.'
Yagnavalkya said: `The eye is its body, ether its place,
and one should worship it as what is true.'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `What is the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> of that which is
true?'
Yagnavalkya replied: `Your Majesty, sight itself (is that
which is true); for if they say to a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> who sees
with his eye, "Didst <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thou</span> see?" and he says, "I saw," then
it is true. Sight, O King, is the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">Highest</span>
Brahman. Sight does not desert him who worships that
(Brahman) with such knowledge, all creatures
approach him, and having become a god, he goes to the
gods.'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `I shall give you (for this) a
<span class="t15 t23 hoverable">thousand</span> cows with a bull as big as an elephant.'
Yagnavalkya said: `My <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">father</span> was of opinion that one
should not accept a reward <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> having fully
instructed a pupil.'
4-1:5. Yagnavalkya said: `Let us hear what anybody may
have told you.'
Ganaka Vaideha replied: `Gardabhivibhita Bharadvaga
told me that hearing ( srotra) is Brahman.'
411

Yagnavalkya said: `As one who had (the benefit of a
good) father, mother, and teacher might tell, so did
Gardabhivibhita Bharadvaga tell you that hearing is
Brahman; for what is the <span class="t4 t18 hoverable">use</span> of a <span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">person</span> who cannot
hear? But did he tell you the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> and the resting-place
of that Brahman?'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `He did not tell me.'
Yagnavalkya said: `Your Majesty, this (Brahman) stands
on one leg only.'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `Then tell me, Yagnavalkya.'
Yagnavalkya said: `The ear is its body, ether its place,
and we should worship it as what is endless.'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `What is the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> of that which is
endless?'
Yagnavalkya replied: `Your Majesty, space (disah) itself
(is that which is endless), and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span> to
whatever space (quarter) he goes, he never comes to the
end of it. For space is endless. Space indeed, O
King, is hearing, and hearing indeed, O King, is the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">Highest</span> Brahman. Hearing does not desert him who
worships that (Brahman) with such knowledge, all
creatures approach him, and having become a god, he
goes to the gods.'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `I shall give you (for this) a
<span class="t15 t23 hoverable">thousand</span> cows with a bull as big as an elephant.'
Yagnavalkya said: `My <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">father</span> was of opinion that one
should not accept a reward <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> having fully
instructed a pupil.'
4-1:6. Yagnavalkya said: `Let us hear what anybody may
have told you.'
Ganaka Vaideha replied: `Satyakama Gabala told me that
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> (manas) is Brahman.'
Yagnavalkya said: `As one who had (the benefit of a
good) father, mother, and teacher might tell, so did
412

Satyakama Gabala tell you that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> is Brahman; for
what is the <span class="t4 t18 hoverable">use</span> of a <span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">person</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> mind? But did
he tell you the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> and the resting-place of that
Brahman?'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `He did not tell me.'
Yagnavalkya said: `Your Majesty, this (Brahman) stands
on one leg only.'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `Then tell me, Yagnavalkya.'
Yagnavalkya said: `Mind itself is its body, ether its place,
and we should worship it as bliss.'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `What is the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> of bliss?'
Yagnavalkya replied: `Your Majesty, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> itself; for with
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> does a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> <span class="t3 t8 t9 t10 t11 t18 t19 t20 hoverable">desire</span> a woman, and a
like <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">son</span> is <span class="t16 t24 hoverable">born</span> of her, and he is bliss. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Mind</span> indeed, O
King, is the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">Highest</span> Brahman. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Mind</span> does not
desert him who worships that (Brahman) with such
knowledge, all creatures approach him, and having
become a god, he goes to the gods.'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `I shall give you (for this) a
<span class="t15 t23 hoverable">thousand</span> cows with a bull as big as an elephant.'
Yagnavalkya said: `My <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">father</span> was of opinion that one
should not accept a reward <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> having fully
instructed a pupil.'
4-1:7. Yagnavalkya said: `Let us hear what anybody may
have told you.'
Ganaka Vaideha replied: `Vidagdha Sakalya told me that
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">heart</span> (hridaya) is Brahman.'
Yagnavalkya said: `As one who had (the benefit of a
good) father, mother, and teacher might tell, so did
Vidagdha Sakalya tell you that the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">heart</span> is Brahman; for
what is the <span class="t4 t18 hoverable">use</span> of a <span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">person</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> a heart? But
did he tell you the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> and the resting-place of that
Brahman?'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `He did not tell me.'
413

Yagnavalkya said: `Your Majesty, this (Brahman) stands
on one leg only.'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `Then tell me, Yagnavalkya.'
Yagnavalkya said: `The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">heart</span> itself is its body, ether its
place, and we should worship it as certainty
(sthiti).'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `What is the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> of certainty?'
Yagnavalkya replied: `Your Majesty, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">heart</span> itself; for
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">heart</span> indeed, O King, is the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> of all
things, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">heart</span> is the resting-place of all things, for in the
heart, O King, all <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">things</span> rest. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">heart</span>
indeed, O King, is the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">Highest</span> Brahman. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">heart</span> does
not desert him who worships that (Brahman)
with such knowledge, all creatures approach him, and
having become a god, he goes to the gods.'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `I shall give you (for this) a
<span class="t15 t23 hoverable">thousand</span> cows with a bull as big as an elephant.'
Yagnavalkya said: `My <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">father</span> was of opinion that one
should not accept a reward <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> having fully
instructed a pupil.'
Section 2
<span class="t2 t3 t5 t10 t12 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">Second</span> Brahmana
4-2:1. Ganaka Vaideha, descending from his throne,
said: `I bow to you, O Yagnavalkya, teach me.'
Yagnavalkya said: `Your Majesty, as a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> who wishes
to make a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">long</span> journey, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> furnish himself
with a chariot or a ship, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> is your <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> furnished
by these Upanishads. You are honourable, and
wealthy, you have learnt the Vedas and been told the
Upanishads. Whither then will you go when
departing hence?'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `Sir, I do not know whither I shall
go.'
414

Yagnavalkya said: `Then I shall tell you this, whither you
will go.'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `Tell it, Sir.'
4-2:2. Yagnavalkya said: `That <span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">person</span> who is in the right
eye, he is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> Indha, and him who is Indha
they <span class="t3 t11 t18 t27 hoverable">call</span> indeed Indra mysteriously, for the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">gods</span> <span class="t0 t2 t5 t7 t8 t13 t15 t17 t18 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">love</span>
what is mysterious, and dislike what is evident.
4-2:3. `Now that which in the shape of a <span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">person</span> is in the
right eye, is his wife, Virag. Their meetingplace is the ether <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span> the heart, and their <span class="t2 t4 t11 t13 hoverable">food</span> the red
lump <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span> the heart. Again, their covering is
that which is like net-work <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span> the heart, and the road
on which they move (from sleep to waking) is
the artery that rises upwards from the heart. Like a hair
divided into a <span class="t15 t23 hoverable">thousand</span> parts, so are the veins of
it, which are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> Hita, placed firmly <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span> the heart.
Through these indeed that (food) flows on
flowing, and he (the Taigasa) receives as it were purer
<span class="t2 t4 t11 t13 hoverable">food</span> than the corporeal Self (the Vaisvanara).
4-2:4. `His (the Taigasa's) Eastern quarter are the pranas
(breath) which go to the East;
`His Southern quarter are the pranas which go to the
South;
`His Western quarter are the pranas which go to the
West;
`His Northern quarter are the pranas which go to the
North;
`His Upper (Zenith) quarter are the pranas which go
upward;
`His Lower (Nadir) quarter are the pranas which go
downward;
`All the quarters are all the pranas. And he (the Atman in
that state) can only be described by No, no! He
is incomprehensible, for he cannot be comprehended; he
is undecaying, for he cannot decay; he is not
415

attached, for he does not attach himself; he is unbound,
he does not suffer, he does not perish. O Ganaka,
you have indeed reached fearlessness,' <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> said
Yagnavalkya.
Then Ganaka said: `May that fearlessness come to you
also who teachest us fearlessness. I bow to you.
Here are the Videhas, and here am I (thy slave).'
Section 3
<span class="t7 hoverable">Third</span> Brahmana
4-3:1. Yagnavalkya came to Ganaka Vaideha, and he did
not mean to <span class="t9 t11 t20 t21 t22 t23 t27 hoverable">speak</span> with him. But when
formerly Ganaka Vaideha and Yagnavalkya had a
disputation on the Agnihotra, Yagnavalkya had granted
him a boon, and he chose (for a boon) that he might be
<span class="t8 t11 t14 t19 hoverable">free</span> to ask him any question he liked.
Yagnavalkya granted it, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> was the first to
ask him a question.
4-3:2. `Yagnavalkya,' he said, `what is the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> of man?'
Yagnavalkya replied: `The sun, O King; for, having the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">sun</span> alone for his light, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> sits, moves about,
does his work, and returns.'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `So indeed it is, O Yagnavalkya.'
4-3:3. Ganaka Vaideha said: `When the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">sun</span> has set, O
Yagnavalkya, what is then the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> of man?'
Yagnavalkya replied: `The moon indeed is his light; for,
having the moon alone for his light, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> sits,
moves about, does his work, and returns.'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `So indeed it is, O Yagnavalkya.'
4-3:4. Ganaka Vaideha said: `When the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">sun</span> has set, O
Yagnavalkya, and the moon has set, what is the
<span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> of man?'
Yagnavalkya replied: `Fire indeed is his light; for, having
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> alone for his light, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> sits, moves about,
does his work, and returns.'
416

4-3:5. Ganaka Vaideha said: `When the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">sun</span> has set, O
Yagnavalkya, and the moon has set, and the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> is
gone out, what is then the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> of man?'
Yagnavalkya replied: `Sound indeed is his light; for,
having sound alone for his light, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> sits, moves
about, does his work, and returns. Therefore, O King,
when one cannot see even one's own hand, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span>
when a sound is raised, one goes towards it.'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `So indeed it is, O Yagnavalkya.'
4-3:6. Ganaka Vaideha said: `When the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">sun</span> has set, O
Yagnavalkya, and the moon has set, and the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> is
gone out, and the sound hushed, what is then the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> of
man?'
Yagnavalkya said: `The Self indeed is his light; for, having
the Self alone as his light, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> sits, moves
about, does his work, and returns.'
4-3:7. Ganaka Vaideha said: `Who is that Self?'
Yagnavalkya replied: `He who is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">within</span> the heart,
surrounded by the Pranas (senses), the <span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">person</span> of light,
consisting of knowledge. He, remaining the same,
wanders along the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> worlds, as if thinking, as if
moving. During sleep (in dream) he transcends this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span>
and all the forms of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">death</span> (all that falls under
the sway of death, all that is perishable).
4-3:8. `On being <span class="t16 t24 hoverable">born</span> that person, assuming his body,
becomes united with all evils; when he departs and
dies, he leaves all evils behind.
4-3:9. `And there are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> states for that person, the one
here in this world, the other in the other world,
and as a <span class="t7 hoverable">third</span> an intermediate state, the <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">state</span> of sleep.
When in that intermediate state, he sees both those
states together, the one here in this world, and the other
in the other world. Now whatever his admission
to the other <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> may be, having gained that admission,
he sees both the evils and the blessings.

417

`And when he falls asleep, then after having <span class="t7 t10 t12 t26 hoverable">taken</span> away
with him the material from the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">whole</span> world,
destroying and building it up again, he sleeps (dreams) by
his own light. In that <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">state</span> the <span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">person</span> is selfilluminated.
4-3:10. `There are no (real) chariots in that state, no
horses, no roads, but he himself sends forth (creates)
chariots, horses, and roads. There are no blessings
there, no happiness, no joys, but he himself sends forth
(creates) blessings, happiness, and joys. There are no
tanks there, no lakes, no rivers, but he himself
sends forth (creates) tanks, lakes, and rivers. He indeed
is the maker.
4-3:11. `On this there are these verses:
`After having subdued by sleep all that belongs to the
body, he, not asleep himself, looks down <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the
sleeping (senses). Having assumed light, he goes again
to his place, the golden person, the lonely bird.
(1)
4-3:12. `Guarding with the breath (prana, life) the lower
nest, the immortal moves away from the nest;
that immortal one goes wherever he likes, the golden
person, the lonely bird. (2)
4-3:13. `Going up and down in his dream, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">god</span> makes
manifold shapes for himself, either rejoicing
<span class="t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t9 t11 t15 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">together</span> with women, or laughing (with his friends), or
seeing terrible sights. (3)
4-3:14. `People may see his playground, but himself no
one ever sees. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Therefore</span> they say, "Let no one
wake a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> suddenly, for it is not easy to remedy, if he
does not get back (rightly to his body)."
`Here some <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> (object and) say: "No, this (sleep) is
the same as the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> of waking, for what he sees
while awake, that only he sees when asleep." No, here
(in sleep) the <span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">person</span> is self-illuminated (as we
explained before).'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `I give you, Sir, a thousand.
<span class="t9 t11 t20 t21 t22 t23 t27 hoverable">Speak</span> on for the sake of (my) emancipation.'
418

4-3:15. Yagnavalkya said: `That (person) having enjoyed
himself in that <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">state</span> of bliss (samprasada, deep
sleep), having moved about and seen both <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> and evil,
hastens back again as he came, to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> from
which he started (the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> of sleep), to dream. And
whatever he may have seen there, he is not followed
(affected) by it, for that <span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">person</span> is not attached to
anything.'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `So it is indeed, Yagnavalkya. I
give you, Sir, a thousand. <span class="t9 t11 t20 t21 t22 t23 t27 hoverable">Speak</span> on for the sake of
emancipation.'
4-3:16. Yagnavalkya said: `That (person) having enjoyed
himself in that sleep (dream), having moved
about and seen both <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> and evil, hastens back again
as he came, to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> from which he started, to
be awake. And whatever he may have seen there, he is
not followed (affected) by it, for that <span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">person</span> is not
attached to anything.'
Ganaka Vaideha said: `So it is indeed, Yagnavalkya. I
give you, Sir, a thousand. <span class="t9 t11 t20 t21 t22 t23 t27 hoverable">Speak</span> on for the sake of
emancipation.'
4-3:17. Yagnavalkya said: `That (person) having enjoyed
himself in that <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">state</span> of waking, having moved
about and seen both <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> and evil, hastens back again
as he came, to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> from which he started, to
the <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">state</span> of sleeping (dream).
4-3:18. `In fact, as a large fish moves along the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span>
banks of a river, the right and the left, so does that
<span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">person</span> move along these <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> states, the <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">state</span> of sleeping
and the <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">state</span> of waking.
4-3:19. `And as a falcon, or any other (swift) bird, after he
has roamed about here in the air, becomes
tired, and folding his wings is carried to his nest, so does
that <span class="t1 t8 t11 t16 t20 t21 t25 t29 hoverable">person</span> hasten to that <span class="t1 t2 t5 t8 t10 t16 t19 hoverable">state</span> where, when
asleep, he desires no more desires, and dreams no more
dreams.
4-3:20. `There are in his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> the veins <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> Hita,
which are as small as a hair divided a thousandfold,
419

full of white, blue, yellow, green, and red. Now when, as
it were, they kill him, when, as it were, they
overcome him, when, as it were, an elephant chases him,
when, as it were, he falls into a well, he fancies,
through ignorance, that danger which he (commonly)
sees in waking. But when he fancies that he is, as it
were, a god, or that he is, as it were, a king, or "I am this
altogether," that is his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t10 t12 t16 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">highest</span> world.
4-3:21. `This indeed is his (true) form, <span class="t8 t11 t14 t19 hoverable">free</span> from desires,
<span class="t8 t11 t14 t19 hoverable">free</span> from evil, <span class="t8 t11 t14 t19 hoverable">free</span> from fear. Now as a man,
when embraced by a beloved wife, knows nothing that is
without, nothing that is within, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> this person,
when embraced by the intelligent (pragna) Self, knows
nothing that is without, nothing that is within.
This indeed is his (true) form, in which his wishes are
fulfilled, in which the Self (only) is his wish, in
which no wish is left, <span class="t8 t11 t14 t19 hoverable">free</span> from any sorrow.
4-3:22. `Then a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">father</span> is not a father, a mother not a
mother, the worlds not worlds, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">gods</span> not gods,
the Vedas not Vedas. Then a thief is not a thief, a
murderer not a murderer, a Kandala not a Kandala, a
Paulkasa not a Paulkasa, a Sramana not a Sramana, a
Tapasa not a Tapasa. He is not followed by good,
not followed by evil, for he has then overcome all the
sorrows of the heart.
4-3:23. `And when (it is said that) there (in the Sushupti)
he does not see, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> he is seeing, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> he
does not see. For sight is inseparable from the seer,
because it cannot perish. But there is then no second,
nothing else different from him that he could see.
4-3:24. `And when (it is said that) there (in the Sushupti)
he does not smell, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> he is smelling, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> he
does not smell. For smelling is inseparable from the
smeller, because it cannot perish. But there is then
no second, nothing else different from him that he could
smell.

second, nothing else different from him that he could

4-3:30. `And when (it is said that) there (in the Sushupti)
he does not know, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> he is knowing, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> he

4-3:31. `When (in waking and dreaming) there is, as it
were, another, then can one see the other, then
can one smell the other, then can one <span class="t9 t11 t20 t21 t22 t23 t27 hoverable">speak</span> to the other,
then can one hear the other, then can one think
the other, then can one touch the other, then can one
know the other.

4-3:32. `An ocean is that one seer, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> any duality;
this is the Brahma-world, O King.' <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Thus</span> did
